journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part J: Journal of Engineering Tribology

title-group.article-title: Anisotropic friction of rugby ball surfaces

article-meta.aff: 1School of Aerospace, Mechanical and Manufacturing Engineering, RMIT University, Australia
2School of Fashion and Textiles, RMIT University, Australia

author-notes.corresp: Franz K Fuss, School of Aerospace, Mechanical and Manufacturing Engineering, RMIT University, Bundoora Campus, Plenty Road, PO Box 71, Bundoora, Melbourne, VIC 3083, Australia. Email: franz.fuss@rmit.edu.au

article-meta.issue-title: Special Issue on Tribology of Sport

abstract.p: In irregular, isotropic surface patterns with randomly distributed roughness elements, the kinetic coefficient of friction is expected to be independent of sliding direction. In regular, anisotropic surface patterns, at least two directions are expected to have different friction coefficients. Five different tackified rugby ball surfaces with different pimple heights and densities were tested; three with irregular (two directions at right angles tested) and two with regular patterns (four directions at 45° angles tested). The friction coefficient and the surface height profile were obtained in a standardised way with the Kawabata friction testing equipment. The average friction coefficients found ranged from 0.94 to 1.25. In the irregular patterns, only one exhibited a significant difference between the two perpendicular directions. In one regular surface, the difference between friction coefficients in two main directions was unexpectedly significant, in the other regular surface, an expected difference in friction coefficient turned out to be non-significant. The coefficient of friction correlated highly with roughness parameters, positively with the arithmetic mean roughness and the average slope of the roughness elements, and negatively with the kurtosis. About 18.3% of the coefficient of friction is accounted for uniquely by the arithmetic mean roughness, 46.1% by a combined contribution of the arithmetic mean roughness and the kurtosis and 0% by unique contribution of the kurtosis.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The roughness geometry of solid surfaces usually originates from machining and/or wear.1 An anisotropic geometrical surface structure is a structure in which the heights and hollows in the surface are clearly oriented.1 The isotropic surface structure consists of a system of asperities without any specified orientation.1 Dry friction, which depends on the direction of sliding as a result of roughness anisotropy of the contacting surfaces, is referred to as anisotropic friction2 or directional friction.3 Typical examples of anisotropic friction occur on surfaces with wedge asperities with unequal gradients on either side of the wedge2 or on snake skin.3 In sport balls with rough surfaces, the directional friction depends on the surface pattern and geometry.

In games that use pressurised sport balls, the precision of catching and throwing and ultimately the speed of the game is inherently related to the grip of the ball: the better the grip, the higher the precision. The grip can be improved either by tackification of the surface or by using gloves. Tackification of the surface is achieved by introducing rough, pimpled surfaces in rugby balls, American footballs and basketballs, as well as in some handballs; rough, ridged surfaces in high quality water polo balls; and the use of resin in handballs. Australian football league balls and most volleyballs have a smooth surface. Some volleyballs come with a structured surface, e.g. with honeycomb ridges/hexagonal dimples or small circular dimples primarily designed for improved aerodynamics.

Presence of ridges or grooves results in vast directional differences of the coefficients of friction along and across the ridges. The grip will be uneven in different directions which will lead to unstable results. These directional differences can be mitigated by aligning the ridges or grooves in two directions, from which dimpled (interrupted grooves and continuous ridges) or pimpled (interrupted ridges and continuous grooves) surfaces result. Preference is given to pimpled surfaces such as knurled handles of tools, anti-slip floor surfaces and car tyres. This is due to not only better fluid drainage properties, but also a softer surface that is easier to be indented by harder pimples than a softer surface protruding into dimples, which becomes clear from surface pressure concentration and distribution.

Friction of elastomers depends on the deformation of the elastomeric surface, on the adhesion and interaction between the two surfaces, on the normal force, on the sliding speed and on the temperature.4–10 Elleuch et al.11 investigated the frictional behaviour of rough elastomers (three different arithmetic mean roughness Ra: 13.2, 6.6 and 3.2 mm; two normal forces: 20 and 40 mN; sliding speed ¼ mm/s; three steel indenter diameters: 4, 5.5 and 9.5 mm). The coefficient of friction (COF) increased with decreasing arithmetic mean roughness due to increasing contact area. The COF also increased with the diameter of the indenter, causing a larger contact area. However, the COF decreased with increasing normal force despite the larger area caused by higher load. This shows that the increase in contact area due to normal force in this study11 was smaller than the one due to decrease in Ra. The same observation – increasing COF with decreasing Ra as a consequence of increasing contact area – was made by Skedung et al.12 and Hendriks and Franklin13 with skin against hard and rough surfaces. According to Briggs and Briscoe,14 the friction force is relatively unchanged by the surface roughness.

For surfaces with triangular ridges, Tomlinson et al.10 found that the COF remained relatively stable rather than decreasing at smaller Ra, and increased with Ra at higher Ra values. This behaviour was interpreted as interlocking of the ridges on the finger pad with the roughness profile,10,15,16 which initiates at relatively low Ra and then propagates with increasing Ra. The interlocking friction coefficient COFi equals (1) where Fi and N are interlocking friction and normal forces, respectively, and θ the angle between slope of a roughness element and the vertical.15
The total friction force is the sum of adhesive, hysteresis and interlocking friction.

Rugby is played in two different forms: rugby league and rugby union football. The main differences between the two forms are that league football has fewer, clearer and simpler rules, and the game is faster with fewer interruptions, which makes it more interesting for spectators but also more athletically demanding for players. The number of players is different as well, with 13 in league football, and 15 in union football. According to the rules of rugby, the material of rugby balls is regulated:17 ‘Leather or suitable synthetic material. It may be treated to make it water resistant and easier to grip’.

The friction between finger skin and rugby ball surfaces was investigated for the first time by Tomlinson18 and Tomlinson et al.19 They analysed four different surfaces with irregular pimple patterns. The pimples were shaped like hemispheres, pyramids or truncated pyramids, where one of the patterns consisted of both smaller and larger pimples. In dry conditions, the kinetic coefficient of friction, COF or µk, ranged from 1.1 to 1.6, with pyramidal pimples outperforming the hemispherical ones independent of the number of pimples per unit area. Tomlinson et al.19 tested the surfaces at a normal force of 12 ± 2.5 N and a sliding speed of 14 ± 6 mm/s.

In this study, Tomlinson et al.19 did neither determine the pimple density and the surface roughness parameters, nor did they correlate the COF to the surface roughness. They did, however, report the number of pimples per total area, as well as the geometrical dimensions of the dimples (height and diameter). As the pimple patterns investigated were irregular, it is not expected that the COF changes with direction. In structured, regular surface patterns, however, the COF is likely to change with direction. In order to assess the directional differences in COF, a standardised objective test method is required instead of relying on several volunteers (possibly with varying finger skin properties) and a slightly varying normal force and sliding speed applied to the surface. The COF in pimpled rubber surfaces behaves non-linearly and depends on sliding speed and normal force.20

A standardised method based on finger skin friction seems impossible due to several aforementioned variables. Equally, any standardised method for determining the COF not using finger skin seems inappropriate due to not matching material. Yet, a compromise is offered by the Kawabata KES_FB4 friction tester (by Kato Tech Co. Ltd, Kyoto, Japan), used for quantification of the friction of fabrics (against ‘skin’) and of the comfort and feel when wearing a fabric. The friction probe of the KES_FB4 testing machine is specifically designed for evaluating the friction between fabrics and a mock ‘finger surface’, built with 10 steel wires, 5 mm long and 0.5 mm in diameter, arranged in series with respect to the sliding direction, which simulates the friction ridges on the finger skin.21 The friction probe is described as ‘used to reproduce the friction of a finger touch on a fabric’22 and ‘simulating finger tips’.23 In addition to the friction probe, the KES_FB4 tester simultaneously measures the surface roughness, however, not on the same spot as the friction is assessed. The roughness probe consists of a single steel wire (5 mm long and 0.5 mm in diameter). The weight of the friction probe is 0.5 N, and the one of the roughness probe is 0.1 N. The sliding speed is 1 mm/s.

The aim of this study is to test rugby ball surfaces with different pimple patterns as to sliding direction-dependent differences in the coefficient of friction and to correlate the coefficient of friction with roughness parameters.

sec.title: Pimpled surfaces and directions tested
sec.p:
We tested five different pimpled surfaces (Table 1; Figure 1) and one smooth surface made of exactly the same rubber compound and produced with the same manufacturing process in the same factory. The surfaces were provided by Gray-Nicolls/Steeden. Three of the five surfaces were covered with irregular patterns. Three irregular patterns are available in commercial balls (national rugby league, rugby union, Japanese rugby balls). The two regular patterns were experimental. All surfaces were magnified 15 times with CAM DIG Microscope QC3247 (by Digitech Computer, Briarcliff Manor, NY, USA) and a digital photo (72 ppi) of each surface was taken. A plastic ruler with a 0.5-mm scale was attached to the surfaces for calibration. On the magnified images, the pimple diameters were measured and the pimple density was determined (Table 1). Figure 1.
Surface patterns investigated: (a) NRL, (b) FIJ, (c) UCO, (d) SNO and (e) REG (Table 1); UCO and SNO: small, medium and large pimples indicated in black, dark grey and light grey, respectively; ‘1’ and ‘2’: perpendicular directions; A, B, C, D and E: main directions of testing. Table 1.
Geometry of surface patterns tested.
Model code Surface pattern Density (%) Pimple diameter (mm)
FIJ Fine Japanese pattern 59.07 0.64
NRL Official pattern of the national rugby league ball 47.32 0.93
UCO Union copy 16.60 Small pimples: 0.72
Small pimples: 5.78 Medium pimples: 0.91
Medium pimples: 2.46 Large pimples: 1.19
Large pimples: 8.37
SNO Snow flake 37.95 Small pimples: 0.58
Small pimples: 2.66 Medium pimples: 0.76
Medium pimples: 7.33 Large pimples: 0.90
Large pimples: 27.96
REG Regular 50.28 1.19

sec.title: Surface geometry

list-item.p: Fine Japanese (FIJ) pattern: this is an irregular pattern with pimples of the same size (0.64 mm in diameter) and a density of 59% (Table 1 and Figure 1).
Official pattern of the national rugby league (NRL) ball: irregular pattern with pimples of the same size (0.93 mm in diameter) and a density of 47%.
Union copy (UCO) pattern: irregular pattern with three different pimple sizes (0.72–1.19 mm in diameter) and an overall density of 17%.
Regular (REG) pattern: orthogonal pattern with pimples of the same size (1.19 mm in diameter) arranged in a Cartesian grid and a density of 50%.

Snow (SNO) flake pattern: consisting of hexagonal clusters of 13 irregularly arranged pimples, forming a hexagonal grid, with three different pimple sizes (0.58–0.9 mm in diameter) and an overall density of 38%. At the cluster level, the pattern is regular and at the pimple level, it is irregular.

sec.p: FIJ and NRL patterns consisted mostly of pimples arranged in sectors of concentric circles, leading in some locations to a pattern similar to REG (regular pattern with two main directions of parallel pimple rows not necessarily perpendicular to each other) and in others to a hexagonal pimple arrangement.

sec.title: Hypotheses
sec.p: If a surface pattern is apparently irregular, then the hypothesis is that the COFs and roughness parameters measured in two perpendicular directions on the surface are expected to be identical. In order to prove or reject this hypothesis, COFs and roughness parameters were measured in two directions in irregular surface patterns. The reason for this is that the surface roughness, seen in side view perpendicularly to the sliding direction, is the same in any direction over a longer sliding distance (depending on the pimple diameter).

If a surface pattern is regular, then, at least in two main directions, the COFs and roughness parameters are hypothetically expected to be different. In an orthogonal pattern, the two main directions with different COFs are at an angle of 45°, whereas perpendicular directions are expected to have the same COF. The reason for this is explained in Figure 2, showing how the surface roughness changes when rotating the direction by 45°. Figure 2.
Different surface profiles of directions A and D of the regular (REG) surface pattern.

sec.title: Directions tested
sec.p: In the three irregular patterns (FIJ, UCO and NRL; Figure 1(a) to (c)), two directions were measured (friction and roughness), i.e. directions ‘1’ and ‘2’, where ‘2’ denotes a direction perpendicular to ‘1’.

In the regular pattern (REG), four directions were measured: A1, A2, D1 and D2 (Figure 1(e)). Direction A followed the parallel rows of pimples. Direction D (diagonal) was at a 45° angle to direction A. As shown in Figure 2, directions A and D are expected to exhibit different COFs. However, in two directions perpendicular to each other, i.e. A1 and A2 or D1 and D2 (Figure 1(e)), no difference is hypothetically expected.

The hexagonal snowflake (SNO) pattern has theoretically six main directions. However, as the hexagonal pattern is non-equiangular, the number of main directions reduces to four, as directions B and C were coincidentally perpendicular. In an equiangular pattern, the directions B and C would be at a 60° angle. Thus, only four directions were measured: A, B, C and E, where A and E are perpendicular as well, however, due to different geometries, unequal COF is expected (Figure 1(d)). If the COFs were expectedly equal, then the directions would be A1 and A2.

sec.title: Friction and surface roughness testing
sec.p: Friction coefficient and roughness height were determined with the Kawabata KES_FB4 test machine (by Kato Tech Co. Ltd, Kyoto, Japan24). Each test consisted of forward and backward slidings on the same area, and friction coefficient and roughness height were measured every 100 µm of sliding. The resolution of roughness height measurement was 10 µm. Each test, after removing the initial, middle (reversal of direction) and final parts of the raw data, resulted in 450 raw data on average. The data removal is implemented in the software of the KES_FB4 test machine and is confined to regions where the transition from static to kinetic friction coefficient occurs. Each direction was measured six times in forward and backward directions (2700 raw data on average).
The pimpled rubber surfaces were glued to 5 mm thick MDF plates and cleaned before each test with alcohol.

sec.title: Data analysis
sec.p: The friction coefficient COF of each direction was calculated from all raw data (mean ± standard deviation; SD). The standard roughness parameters Ra, Rq, Rsk and Rku were determined from the raw data of the roughness height of each of the six tests by means of the following equations (2) (3) (4) (5) where z is the local surface height and n the number of z data. Here, Ra is the basic arithmetic mean roughness parameter. Rq is required for calculating Rsk and Rku. Rsk is related to the directional pimple density; Ra and Rku are related to the steepness of the pimple slopes. Mean and SD were calculated from the 12 (six times forward and backward) Ra, Rq, Rsk and Rku data per direction.
The average cotangent of the slope angle θ is calculated from (6) where Δx = 0.1 mm.24

The COF data of each direction and surface were compared as to the significance of difference by applying the t-test (significance level at p < 0.05). The log-transformed COF data (mean of the 12 data; six times forward and backward) and untransformed cot θ data were correlated to the untransformed and log-transformed roughness data with a multiple regression analysis and the coefficients of correlation and determination were determined.

sec.title: Surface geometry
sec.p: The density of the five surfaces is listed in Table 1, ranging from 16.60% (UCO) to 59.07% (FIJ). Three surfaces (NRL, FIJ and REG) consisted of uniform pimples. UCO and SNO had pimples of three different sizes (Table 1 and Figure 1).

Due to the dimensions of the roughness probe (5 mm long and 1 mm in diameter), pimples arranged in parallel (along the axis of the friction probe) were superimposed across the probe width and resulted in a combined roughness profile (Figure 2). For example, the Ra of REG_A was 272 µm (maximal Ra measured), whereas the Ra of the diagonal REG_D was only 175 µm. The minimal Ra was found in the FIJ pattern (69 µm).

sec.title: Average coefficient of friction
sec.p: The surface with the highest average COF was REG (1.218 ± 0.041), followed by the smooth surface (1.125 ± 0.083), NRL (1.107 ± 0.050), UCO (1.020 ± 0.022), SNO (1.013 ± 0.026) and FIJ (0.941 ± 0.017). The difference between all surfaces was significant at p < 0.0001.

sec.title: Directional coefficient of friction
sec.p:
The COF data are shown in Figure 3. The average COF ranged from 0.9412 (FIJ) to 1.253 (REG_A1). The difference in COF between directions ‘1’ and ‘2’ (perpendicular to each other) was not significant (p < 0.05) in the following surfaces and main directions: FIJ, UCO, and REG_D. The largest (significant) difference in COF between directions ‘1’ and ‘2’ was found in the NRL pimple pattern (ΔCOF = 0.084; p < 0.0001), followed by REG_A1/A2 (ΔCOF = 0.031; p < 0.0001). Only two main directions showed a non-significant difference in COF: SNO_A and SNO_C (Figure 3). The COFs of all other main directions were significantly different. Figure 3.
Kinetic COF µk data of directions 1 and 2 combined if non-significant difference; note that this figure shows box plots (box-and-whisker diagrams) with median, lower and upper quartiles (50% of all data within the box), and the range of all data (the ends of whiskers do not represent the SD); *no significant difference.

sec.title: Correlation of friction, roughness parameters and slope angle
sec.p:
The general trend found suggests that the higher Ra and the smaller Rku, the higher is the COF (Figures 4 and 5). Based on a non-linear power regression, the coefficients of correlation were: COF against Ra: +0.80 (p < 0.0001); and COF against Rku: −0.68 (p < 0.0001). The COF did not correlate with Rsk (r = 0.36; p < 0.0001; linear fit). Ra and Rku correlated with each other at r = −0.84 (p < 0.0001; power fit; Figure 6). The correlation graphs including mean and SD7 of COF, Ra and Rku are shown in Figures 4 and 5. There was no correlation between COF and pimple density or diameter. Figure 4.
Kinetic COF µk against Ra; thin dashed line: non-linear regression (power fit). Figure 5.
Kinetic COF µk against Rku; thin dashed line: non-linear regression (power fit). Figure 6.
Ra against Rku; thin dashed line: non-linear regression (power fit).

The results indicate that the higher Ra and the smaller Rku, the larger is the COF. However, as Ra and Rku correlate highly with each other, a multiple regression analysis is required for determining which of the two factors is the dominating one for producing a larger COF. From the individual coefficients of determination, 64.4% (rRa 2 = 0.644) of the COF magnitude can be explained from Ra, however only 46.1% (rRku 2 = 0.461) of the magnitude from Rku. The multiple R2 (RRa-RHu 2) was 0.644. From Venn diagram analysis, the unique and combined contribution of Ra and Rku to COF is determined as follows:
unique contribution of Ra + combined Ra–Rku contribution = rRa 2 = 0.644
unique contribution of Rku + combined Ra–Rku contribution = rRku 2 = 0.461
unique Ra contribution + unique Rku contribution +combined Ra–Rku contribution = RRa-RHu 2 = 0.644 Thus,
unique contribution of Ra = 0.183
unique contribution of Rku = 0
combined Ra–Rku contribution = 0.461 In other words,
18.3% of the COF variance is accounted for uniquely by Ra;
46.1% of the COF variance is accounted for by the combined predictors Ra and Rku;
Rku alone has no influence (0%) on the COF variance; and
35.6% of the COF variance is unaccounted for.
The COF correlates highly with the average cotangent of the slope angle θ (r = 0.796, r2 = 0.634; p < 0.0001; Figure 7). Thus, 63.4% of the COF are due to cot θ.
Ra and Rku correlate with cot θ at r = 0.650 and r = 0.485, respectively. The multiple regression R2 = 0.659 (p < 0.0001). From Venn diagram analysis
17.4% of the cot θ variance is accounted for uniquely by Ra;
47.6% of the cot θ variance is accounted for by the combined predictors Ra and Rku;
0.9% of the cot θ variance is accounted for uniquely by Rku; and
34.1% of the cot θ variance is unaccounted for.
Figure 7.
Kinetic COF µk against cot θ; thin dashed line: linear regression.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: In irregular surface patterns with randomly distributed roughness elements and direction-independent geometry, the kinetic coefficient of friction is expected to be independent of sliding direction. However, a statistically significant difference in COF between directions ‘1’ and ‘2’ of the irregular NRL was found. Minimum and maximum average COFs of the six spots of NRL1 were 1.13 and 1.16, and of NRL2 were 1.04–1.09. Thus, the average COF data of NRL1 and NRL2 are not overlapping and rather separated by a gap from COF 1.09 to 1.13. However, there is no null-based statistical evidence that this behaviour is due to the pimple geometry as the roughness parameters Ra, Rsq and Rku show no statistically significant difference between NRL1 and NRL2. Nevertheless, from magnitude-based statistics, the general trend remains the same: the higher Ra, the larger is the COF.

In regular surface patterns, at least two directions are expected to have different friction coefficients, as the pimple geometry changes (Figures 1 and 2). In one regular surface, the difference between friction coefficients in two main directions was unexpectedly significant (REG_A1 and REG_A2), in the other regular surface, an expected difference in friction coefficient turned out to be non-significant (SNO_A and SNO_C). The unexpectedly significant difference between REG_A1 and REG_A2 could be attributed to the significant difference in Rku. Despite a striking difference in Ra and Rku, the COF of SNO_A and SNO_C are not different from each other.

The COF correlates with Ra, Rku and cot θ; cot θ in turn correlates with Ra and Rku. From the coefficient of determination, cot θ contributes most to the COF. According to equation (1), the interlocking COF, one of the three components of the overall COF, equals cot θ.15 The interlocking friction force is produced by the interaction of the pimpled surface and the surface of the friction probe, consisting of steel cylinders (0.5 mm in diameter), arranged in series. The adhesive friction is dependent on area and normal load. The COF of the smooth surface tested is significantly smaller (by 8%) than the one of the pimpled surface with the highest COF. This indicates that the COF increases with contact area, however, interlocking is more dominant than adhesion.

The COF data obtained by Tomlinson et al.19 cannot be directly compared to the data of this study, as Tomlinson et al.19 obtained their data at different normal loads (12 ± 2.5 N) and velocities (14 ± 6 mm/s) compared to the KES_FB4 tester (0.5 N, 1 mm/s). The reason for this is that the COF behaves highly non-linearly.

Fuss20 investigated the non-linear friction (velocity and force dependency) between the finger skin and surface REG (direction A; Figure 1(e)) at different speeds and normal forces. The COF data obtained at the same speed and load as that of the KES_FB4 friction probe fell between 1.1 and 1.3. The average data of surface REG, direction A, determined with the KES_FB4 friction probe delivered 1.237 ± 0.119. Although the KES_FB4 friction probe consists of steel, and not of finger skin, the data obtained with both methods are in good agreement, which justifies the applicability of the KES_FB4 friction for the assessment of directional friction of rugby ball surfaces.

The directional differences of the COF in rugby ball surfaces are insofar important, as the oval ball is handled in different ways. When catching, the ball can, in the worst case, only slip between the hands in axial direction. When throwing a pass, the ball is accelerated in axial direction (same as deceleration of a caught ball) and at the same time an axial (rifle) spin is applied by the fingers,19 sliding over the surface perpendicularly to the long axis. It is thus essential that the directions of maximal COF are aligned axially and circumferentially.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: As a general trend across the five surfaces tested, the coefficient of friction correlates positively with the arithmetic mean roughness and the average slope of the roughness elements, and negatively with the kurtosis.
Within a surface of irregular pimple pattern, unexpected directional differences in COF between two perpendicular directions can occur.
A surface of regular pimple pattern can show unexpected differences or similarities in COF between main directions.
Unexpected friction behaviour does not always deviate from the general trend, as unexpectedness is null-based and not magnitude-based.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This study was supported by Gray-Nicolls Sports Pty Ltd.

sec.title: Conflict of interest
sec.p: The authors declare that there is no conflict of interest.
